Are you using spark max motor controllers? If so, you can go into REV hardware client and turn it into ‚Äúbrake‚Äù mode that way it holds its position.

I think the problem with it falling down after turning off can be fixed by that. You‚Äôll know if it‚Äôs in brake mode if the light on the motor controller is a cyan color. I think you have an encoder error for it going too high though. Try lowering your encoder target?

Hi again!

Sorry for the delay, my lunch break school ended, so I had to go back to class. Does this part of your code print out encoder values correctly?

I‚Äôm wondering if maybe you set up your encoder incorrectly and it‚Äôs not actually counting properly, so it doesn‚Äôt know when to stop?

If that‚Äôs not the case, I think there could be something wrong with the way that you add buttons to your commands. Instead of the way you have it:

You could maybe try seeing if this code I wrote works:

Basically what I did was add a default case to make sure that when the button isn‚Äôt pressed, the power on the elevator is turned off. I also added a print statement to check if the setpoint is set correctly to make sure that the setpoint=target encoder. Let me know if this helps at all and what results of this code that way I can try to help you more later.

I‚Äôm wondering if maybe you set up your encoder incorrectly and it‚Äôs not actually counting properly, so it doesn‚Äôt know when to stop?

I am using the built in encoder for the neo brushless motor. is that alright?

Try putting them in brake mode, they won‚Äôt hold their positions without it.

Yes, the built-in neo encoders should be fine. Did you try the code I sent you? I think something may be wrong with the way you use encoders in your code.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-21T18:18:48.066Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":10.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":496356,"topic_slug":"elevator-not-working-correctly","display_username":"Micah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":74317,"username":"FRC_Member_apex","name":"Ertu","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/e480ec/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69912,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer üíª"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-not-working-correctly/496356/12","custom_user_title":"Lead Programmer üíª","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3564778,"name":"Andrew Todd","username":"Andrew123ast","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew123ast/{size}/243883_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T18:24:58.913Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôd recommend following the documentation:

docs.revrobotics.com

Closed Loop Control Getting Started | REVLib

Here‚Äôs the example code too:

github.com

REVrobotics/REVLib-Examples/blob/main/Java/SPARK/Closed Loop Control/src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java

/*----------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
/* Copyright (c) 2017-2018 FIRST. All Rights Reserved.                        */
/* Open Source Software - may be modified and shared by FRC teams. The code   */
/* must be accompanied by the FIRST BSD license file in the root directory of */
/* the project.                                                               */
/*----------------------------------------------------------------------------*/

package frc.robot;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.TimedRobot;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SmartDashboard;

import com.revrobotics.RelativeEncoder;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkLowLevel.MotorType;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkClosedLoopController;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkMax;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkBase.ControlType;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkBase.PersistMode;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkBase.ResetMode;
import com.revrobotics.spark.config.SparkMaxConfig;
This file has been truncated. show original

If I am understanding your code correctly, you‚Äôre only calling the calculate once rather than in a loop so it calculates a single point and won‚Äôt work right. Using the REV examples, it will continuously handle the PID control and you don‚Äôt have to worry about it (make sure they‚Äôre in brake mode as mentioned above).

You‚Äôll still need to do some math for the heights. The internal encoder outputs revolutions if I remember correctly. We converted that to inches with some funky math, but you can also just measure rotations empirically. I recommend checking out advantage scope if you have time.

WPILIB has example projects that include an Elevator Profiled PID controller.

This will create an Elevator Subsystem with the code. The WPILIB documentation has directions on how to tune the PID controller terms.

So why does the elevator fall?
There is a term that applies a constant voltage to keep the elevator held at the current level. The particular value of the voltage term, vg, based upon the weight of your elevator and gear box connected to your motors.

Turning on break mode of the motor controller will help keep it up as well.

Here is the code for our elevator subsystem. We used the base code from WPILIB to get started. We added one limit switch for the top. We also have an enable / disable elevator since we intake from the back, pass it through the elevator and into our outtake. We use a beam break to detect if a coral has not cleared the elevator yet. Once it clears we enable it to move. We did this to prevent breaking our elevator.

Link to our source code here
compbot-2025/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Elevator.java at Comp1 ¬∑ frc6239/compbot-2025 ¬∑ GitHub

Our code is on the comp1 branch. We have not merged it back into the main branch yet.

When using a SparkMax with a Neo, I would recommend using Revs position control mode (Position Control Mode | REVLib). There is a good example available available based on TimedRobot, like yours (SPARK-MAX-Examples/Java/Position Closed Loop Control/src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java at master ¬∑ REVrobotics/SPARK-MAX-Examples ¬∑ GitHub).

Taking a look at the introductory sections before the position control section would be good too. They this one (Closed Loop Control | REVLib) and its first two sub-sections.

I am trying to arrange my schedule to be able to come by your lab again tomorrow. We can dig in on this then.

Since I have not seen your elevator yet, I have a couple of questions. When intaking a coral, is the elevator all the way down and all movements to score are upward? If so, tuning can be simplified a bit. Also, is there a limit switch in place at the bottom for zeroing the elevator encoder upon return to the bottom? This would be a good idea. A switch positioned to trip a bit before max extension would be good too for safety.

This is close, but will still cause some issues. Notably:

  • It sets the motor multiple times per loop, which is suboptimal and causes subtle jumps
  • doesn‚Äôt provide the correct ‚Äúhold‚Äù output needed to keep the elevator up

It does correctly detect OP‚Äôs main issue: When the PID control is stopped due to releasing a button, the final value sent to the motor from motor.set() is likely nonzero and positive, which will normally continue forward motion at the speed it was going when the button was released.

The elevator control should optimally set the appropriate value once per loop, and utilize the gravity feedforward to hold it at the current position when not being driven somewhere. This should do it.

  public void teleopPeriodic() {
    //mydrive.tankDrive(cont1.getLeftY(), cont1.getRightY());
    mydrive.arcadeDrive(-cont1.getLeftY(), -cont1.getRightX());

    System.out.println("encoder elevator"+elevatorencoder.getPosition());
    
    if(cont1.getXButton()){
      setPosition(reef_bottom);
    }
    else if(cont1.getAButton()){
      setPosition(reef_level2);
    }
    else if(cont1.getLeftBumperButton()){
      setPosition(reef_level3);
    }
   else{
     elevator.set(GRAVITY_COMPENSATION);
   }
}

This should be fine. The simplest fix for this is to set up a duty cycle on your NEO 500‚Äôs and have a command calling upon a constant that spins the motors in an elevator up position as to where it holds it‚Äôs position. Make sure that when you go down you are not using this hold up command/constant or else your elevator will get stuck and your NEO‚Äôs will be stressed. Let me know if something goes wrong or you have any questions on how to implement this. I hope this helps you some. (edit) Make sure that the HOLD UP constant is being run after you reach your set state. When you hit a lower level, your elevator should let go of this command allowing you to go back up. Again, any questions feel free to ask.
